title: Domain 1.9: Given a scenario, perform OS installations and upgrades in a diverse OS environment.
content:
ðŸ’» Boot Methods

  • USB: Common method using a bootable USB drive with the OS installer.
  • Optical Media: Boot from CD/DVD â€” used less now but still supported.
  • Network (PXE): Installs OS over the network, ideal for enterprise deployments.
  • Solid-state/Flash Drives: Use external flash-based storage for OS installation.
  • Internet-Based: Boot directly from cloud or internet-based server.
  • External/Hot-Swappable Drives: Boot from external HDDs or SSDs.
  • Internal Hard Drive (Partition): Boot and install from a local recovery or setup partition.

ðŸ”§ Types of Installations

  • Upgrade: Install newer OS version while keeping files/apps/settings.
  • Recovery Partition: Restore from pre-installed OEM recovery partition.
  • Clean Install: Full OS install â€” wipes existing data.
  • Image Deployment: Uses a system image to quickly install OS and apps.
  • Repair Installation: Fixes a broken OS without deleting files.
  • Remote Network Installation: Install via network (e.g., PXE boot or WDS).
  • Other Considerations: Ensure third-party drivers are loaded during install if needed (e.g., RAID, GPU, Wi-Fi).

ðŸ’½ Drive Format & Upgrade Considerations

  • Backup Files and Settings: Always back up before upgrading to avoid data loss.
  • App and Driver Compatibility: Check if older software and hardware work with the new OS.
  • Hardware Compatibility: Ensure that the system meets OS requirements and drivers are available.
  • Product Life Cycle: Make sure the OS version isn't near end-of-life and will receive updates.
